docs.lead_paragraph: Growth is steady, but slow. Suppliers are not raising their prices, but nobody else can either. Costs have been cut deeply in a decade of downsizing, leaving few easy options for improving the bottom line. What is a chief executive hungry for greater earnings to do? In 1996, the answer was to eat somebody else's company.

headline.main: Conditions Are Right for a Takeover Frenzy

docs.abstract: Corporations are expected to continue looking to mergers as source of growth in 1997, following year in which merger deals soared to over $647 billion; see acquisitions as way to increase profit margins, expand unit growth and control costs; major obstacle to merger wave is number of big targets that have already been bought; graphs; table (M)
docs.snippet: Growth is steady, but slow. Suppliers are not raising their prices, but nobody else can either. Costs have been cut deeply in a decade of downsizing, leaving few easy options for improving the bottom line.    What is a chief executive hungry for...

docs.lead_paragraph: For hospitals and health insurers in New York State, the new year promises to be one of the most turbulent ever as a new law takes effect lifting price controls on hospitals and forcing them to compete in an increasingly cutthroat health care market. For the last 15 years, state regulators have fixed what hospitals could charge the insurers and health maintenance organizations that send them patients, a system that critics said removed the incentive for hospitals to hold down costs. But yesterday at midnight, those regulations expired. As of today every hospital and insurer in New York is free to negotiate their own deals, and may the best company remain solvent.

headline.main: HOSPITALS START OPEN COMPETITION UNDER A NEW LAW

docs.abstract: New year promises to be one of most turbulent ever for hospitals and health insurers in New York State, as new law takes effect lifting price controls on hospitals and forcing them to compete in increasingly cutthroat health care market; health care experts are awed by magnitude of transition under way and reluctant to make predictions on its outcome; say that patients should not be affected by the turmoil for the moment, but that over time, the overhaul will push more patients into HMO's and help cut insurance premiums (M)
docs.snippet: For hospitals and health insurers in New York State, the new year promises to be one of the most turbulent ever as a new law takes effect lifting price controls on hospitals and forcing them to compete in an increasingly cutthroat health care market....

docs.lead_paragraph: NORMA LEVORSON spent a quiet Christmas with her husband, Jerry, at their home in Albert Lea, Minn., and said she enjoyed it thoroughly. A few years ago, the couple spent another ''delightful'' Christmas at a lovely hotel in Chicago, where they attended a neighborhood church and a theatrical opening. ''Delight'' was not always the emotion she associated with Christmas. Years ago, in the throes of a depression and with her parents dead and her children dispersed, Christmas filled Mrs. Levorson with paralyzing anxiety about not being able to have the big family-centered picture book holiday so often portrayed on television. What has made the difference, Mrs. Levorson says -- not just in her enjoyment of whatever the holidays may bring but in her ability to participate in and get pleasure from many ordinary aspects of life -- has been a self-help group called Recovery Inc.
docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column on Recovery Inc, self-help group founded nearly 60 years ago by Chicago psychiatrist, Dr Abraham C Low, to help chronically nervous people get well and help former mental patients stay well; Recovery Inc has expanded internationally and, through 700 groups, now serves hundreds of thousands of people who want to improve their emotional well-being; participants include ordinary people who lives are impaired by anxiety, depression, panic attacks, excessive stress and nervousness who may never have consulted a mental health professional, as well as patients currently or formerly in treatment for serious emotional problems (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The Horizon/CMS Health Care Corporation said today that it had paid $5.8 million to the Federal Government to settle an investigation of insurance billings. The company reached the settlement with the United States Attorney's office in New Mexico and the Department of Health and Human Services. The company said the Federal Government declined any criminal prosecution and would not exclude Horizon/CMS from Medicare and Medicaid programs. The company said the investigation was related to Medicare billings. Horizon/CMS, which operates in 35 states, said the $5.8 million it paid included $1.2 million refunded to the Federal Government in April.
docs.abstract: Horizon/CMS Health Care Corp pays $5.8 million to Federal Government to settle an investigation of insurance billings (S)
